Service Evolution Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(3) Focus on the Service Surface

  • APIs are supposed to hide implementation details
    • Your data model is not your object model
    • Your object model is not your resource model
    • Your resource model is not your message model
  • Designing APIs is a conscious and explicit design exercise
    • API First looks at API design as product mockup/prototype
    • Design Thinking looks at APIs from the UX/DX [Documentation; Developer Experience (DX) (1)] perspective
  • Designing changeability into the API is a key requirement


Service Evolution Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(4) Autonomy vs. Robustness

  • APIs emphasize independence and autonomy of components
    • Allowing teams to design/implement/deploy autonomously increases speed
    • With no oversight at all the cost may add up on the consumer side
    • Finding a harmonious balance between autonomy and guidelines is key
  • There are two critical sides to the evolution part
    1. When services change [Design for Service Evolution (1)], do consumers need to be aware of the changes?
    2. When the landscape changes [Design for Landscape Evolution (1)], do consumers need to discover the new services?


Service Evolution Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(5) Design for Service Evolution

  • Services are designed with a certain goal and certain options
    • The goal is to satisfy the current requirements for a useful service
    • The options are based on assumptions on how the service might change
  • Service design is a balance between simplicity and flexibility
  • Building robust and extensible services [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2016/04/robust-extensibility.html] is based on three factors
    • Meaningful and stable core: The service core must remain stable over time
    • Extension model: There are well-defined ways how the service core may evolve
    • Processing model: It is well-defined how clients are processing extensions


Service Evolution Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(6) Design for Landscape Evolution

  • Application flow should be guided by discovered controls
    • A dynamic service landscape needs a dynamic way of discovering services
    • Hypermedia [Hypermedia] is a proven way how controls can be served dynamically
  • Hypermedia is a good way for supporting service choreography
    • API usage may change over time as the landscape evolves
    • Choreography exposes ways in which various services are combined to achieve a goal
  • If nobody uses APIs, these may disappear over time
    • Usage and linkage combined provide useful analysis data

Designing Objects Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(8) Accessing Domain Objects

  • Access operations might provide direct access to domain objects
    • Listing objects through some form of access path
    • Querying for objects based on some query capabilities
  • Reading objects should not directly expose implementation details
    • Implementation technology should not affect the API
    • Having a meaningful and stable core establishes a solid foundation
    • Having well-defined extension points allows service evolution


Designing Objects Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(9) Picking a Metamodel

  • For many APIs there is some bias in the resources they expose
    • Object orientation means it is about distinct and structured objects
    • Document orientation means a focus on rich text representation and structures
    • Graph orientation means less focus on explicitly distinct objects
  • Picking the right metamodel means having a better model
    • Any metamodel can be used to represent any model
    • Picking the right tool for the job results in a better API
  • Keep the developer/user community and their preferences in mind


Designing Objects Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(10) Designing a Model

  • Documenting design decisions is as important as documenting a design
    • Developers are happier when they know the reasons for a specific design
  • Consider using/extending established domain models
    • Open/extensible domain models are reasonable candidates
    • Reuse is good but forcing it can result in design issues
    • Consider the overall complexity of any reused designs

Designing Messages Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(12) Web APIs and Messaging

  • APIs are about exchanging messages that request resources or resource state changes
    • Requesting a resource results in a resource representation
    • Requesting a resource state change often needs additional details
  • Designing API messages is like designing paper forms
    • Self-contained representations of the requested state changes
    • Responses may indicate further required interactions
    • Follow the workflow as required to achieve the end result
  • Responses often are a combination of content and control elements
    • Data is some representation of an (intermediary) result
    • Control allows clients to engage in further interactions
    • Equivalent to paper forms combining confirmation/continuation information


Designing Messages Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(13) Messaging and Workflows

  • Hypermedia [Hypermedia] combines content and control information
    • Messages contain information about resources in the workflow
    • Messages contain information about next steps in the workflow
  • Clients are achieving goals by using messages in a guided way
    • If guidance is embedded: Choreography (driven by inline guidance from APIs)
    • If guidance is external: Orchestration (driven by out-of-line guidance)
  • Workflow variability means that hypermedia helps clients
    • Controls are only present if they represent possible follow-up interactions
    • Clients can adapt their behavior based on available controls


Designing Messages Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

(14) Messaging Formats

  • Message formats combine content and control information
    • Some scenarios allow to separate content and control information
  • Data/control separation is an effective simplification
    • Data representation can be based on an existing object design [Designing Objects (1)]
    • Control representation adds information that clients can navigate
  • Using existing formats can improve API landscape consistency
    • Examples of existing JSON-based formats are HAL, Siren, Collection+JSON, and UBER


Designing Messages Erik Wilde (erik.wilde@dret.net): Representation Design

    "self": {"href": "/orders"},
    "next": {"href": "/orders?page=2"},
    "http://example.com/docs/rels/find": {
      "href": "/orders{?id}",
      "templated": true },
    "http://example.com/docs/rels/admin": [
      { "href": "/admins/2",
        "title": "Fred" },
      { "href": "/admins/5",
        "title": "Kate" }]},
  "currentlyProcessing": 14,
  "shippedToday": 20,
  "_embedded": {"http://example.com/docs/rels/order": [
    { "_links": {
        "self": {"href": "/orders/123"},
        "http://example.com/docs/rels/basket": {"href": "/baskets/98712"},
        "http://example.com/docs/rels/customer": {"href": "/customers/7809"}},
      "total": 30,
      "currency": "USD",
      "status": "shipped"},
    { "_links": {
        "self": {"href": "/orders/124"},
        "http://example.com/docs/rels/basket": {"href": "/baskets/97213"},
        "http://example.com/docs/rels/customer": {"href": "/customers/12369"} },
      "total": 20,
      "currency": "USD",
      "status": "processing" }]}}
